comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: I found mention in Aerial Age Weekly of a General Liu Tsching-En of the Chinese Army, director of the Hanyang Arsenal at Hupeh China, visiting the Curtiss factory at Buffalo in 1915...from there, worked out that he's General T. E. Liu, who contracted with Pratt and Whitney to produce prototypes of his rifle design in Connecticut. The "Liu Rifle" is a rarity because much of the initial shipment was lost at sea, and it was never put into production in China. Video here about the Liu Rifle talks about General Liu: www.forgottenweapons.com/bin-shih-and-the-general-liu-rifle

comment.author: 35234565@N04
comment._content: This information is very cool pennylrichardsca. A fascinating story.  Can anyone read the date? Do you think it's Sept. 1914 when Gen. Liu visited the U.S.?  Interesting, too, that he is posed with a sword.  Thanks so much for your research.  We'll add some of the information to the record the next time we update.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: the date on the negative is 10/30/14, but it's a formal portrait, so it may be from a different time.
